[[Foster Farms Bowl]] ([[NCAA]]) (2014–present) | website = {{URL|levisstadium.com}} | publictransit = {{rail-interchange|santaclara}} [[Great America (VTA)|Great America]]
{{rail-interchange|us|amtrak}}{{rail-interchange|ace}} [[Santa Clara – Great America Station|Santa Clara – Great America]] | image_size = 275px | address = 4900 Marie P DeBartolo Way{{cite news|last=Rosenberg|first=Mike|title=49ers Stadium's New Street Address in Santa Clara Named After Team Luminaries|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_22767343/49ers-stadiums-new-street-address-santa-clara-named|newspaper=The Mercury News|date=March 12, 2013|accessdate=October 8, 2013}} | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]1.3 billion (est) | main_contractor = [[Cupertino Electric]]: Electrical and Fire Alarm systems. | former_names = | seating_capacity = 68,500 (expandable to 75,000){{cite web|title=About Levi’s® Stadium|url=http://www.levisstadium.com/about-levis-stadium/|website=LevisStadium.com|accessdate=June 26, 2018}} }} [[File:Levi's Stadium from air.jpg|thumb|Levi's Stadium from a tower at [[California's Great America]] theme park.]] '''Levi's Stadium''' is a [[American football|football]] stadium located in [[Santa Clara, California]], in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]]. It has served as the home venue for the [[National Football League]] (NFL)'s [[San Francisco 49ers]] since 2014. The stadium is located approximately {{Convert|40|mi}} south of San Francisco and is named for [[Levi Strauss & Co.]], which purchased [[naming rights]] in 2013. In 2006, the 49ers initially proposed constructing a new stadium at [[Candlestick Point State Recreation Area|Candlestick Point]] in [[San Francisco]], the site of their existing home, [[Candlestick Park]]. The project, which included plans for retail space and housing improvements, was claimed to be of great potential benefit to the nearby historically [[blight (urban)|blighted]] neighborhood of [[Hunters Point, San Francisco, California|Hunters Point]]. After negotiations with the city of San Francisco fell through, the 49ers focused their attention on a site adjacent to their administrative offices and training facility in Santa Clara. In June 2010, Santa Clara voters approved a measure authorizing the creation of the Santa Clara Stadium Authority, a tax-exempt public authority, to build and own the new football stadium and for the city government to lease land to the Santa Clara Stadium Authority.{{cite news|url= http://www.latimes.com/business/realestate/la-fi-stadium-goldman-20150524-story.html |title=In stadium financing game, Goldman Sachs dominates|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=May 23, 2015|first=Tim |last=Logan}} A construction loan, raised from private investors, was secured in December 2011, allowing construction to start in April 2012.{{cite news |title=49ers' Kick Off Move to Santa Clara With Far-From-Traditional Groundbreaking|first=Mike|last=Rosenberg|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/southbayfootball/ci_20434376/49ers-break-ground-this-evening-stadium-at-center|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=April 19, 2012|accessdate=May 6, 2012}} Levi's Stadium opened on July 17, 2014. Levi's Stadium hosted [[Super Bowl 50]] on February 7, 2016.{{cite web |title=San Francisco Awarded Super Bowl L; Houston Lands LI|first=Gregg|last=Rosenthal|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000205086/article/san-francisco-awarded-super-bowl-l-houston-lands-li|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=May 21, 2013|accessdate=May 21, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Naranjo|first=Candice|title=The Super Bowl is Coming to Levi’s Stadium in 2016|url=http://news.kron4.com/news/the-super-bowl-is-coming-to-levis-stadium-in-2016/|publisher=KRON 4|accessdate=28 March 2014}} Levi's Stadium also serves as the site of the [[Pac-12 Football Championship Game]] since 2014. Previously, the game was played at the home stadium of the division winner with the better record entering the game.{{cite web |url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000350321/article/pac12-to-move-football-championship-game-to-levis-stadium |title=Pac-12 to move football championship game to Levi's Stadium |author=Bryan Fischer |date= May 14, 2014 |publisher=NFL.com |accessdate=2014-05-15}}{{cite news |title=Pac-12 announces deal to host Football Championship Game at Levi's Stadium |url=http://pac-12.com/article/2014/05/15/pac-12-announces-deal-host-football-championship-game-levis-stadium |date=May 15, 2014 |publisher=[[Pac-12 Conference]] |work=Pac-12.Com |accessdate=August 24, 2014}} ==Stadium design== The stadium was designed by [[HNTB]], an internationally renowned architectural firm, with a focus on creating a multi-purpose venue and with the fan experience and green technology as top priorities. Civil engineering work was performed by [[Winzler & Kelly]], which was acquired by [[GHD Group]] in 2011. Commissioning services were provided by Glumac. ===Basic stadium features=== Levi's Stadium is designed as an open stadium with a natural grass field. It has a seating capacity of 68,500, expandable to approximately 75,000 to host major events like the [[Super Bowl]] and the [[FIFA World Cup]]. However, on June 27, 2015, The Grateful Dead Fare Thee Well Tour made history by extending the stadium to 83,000 in attendance. The seating design of the stadium places approximately two-thirds of the fans in the lower bowl, which is one of the largest of its kind in the entire NFL. The design features significantly improved accessibility and seating options for fans with special needs and disabilities when compared to Candlestick Park. The configuration is similar to [[Ford Field]], home of the NFL's [[Detroit Lions]], with the majority of the [[luxury box|luxury suites]] on one side of the field, which puts the fans in the upper deck closer to the action. As a multi-use facility, the stadium can be configured for special touring events including concerts, motocross events, indoor/outdoor conferences, and other community events. The stadium is also designed to meet the FIFA field geometry requirements for international soccer, which will allow it to host international friendly matches and major tournaments such as the FIFA World Cup. The stadium will also feature over {{convert|109000|sqft|m2}} of flexible premium meeting space in the club areas.{{cite web|title=Stadium Design |url=http://www.santaclarastadiumfacts.com/images/stories/Stadium+Design+Measure+J.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306015445/http://www.santaclarastadiumfacts.com/images/stories/Stadium%2BDesign%2BMeasure%2BJ.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 6, 2012 |publisher=Santa Clara Stadium |date=April 20, 2010 |accessdate=April 20, 2010 |df= }} ====Stadium app==== The stadium has created an in stadium app designed specifically for home football games for the 49ers to provide a better fan experience for fans and guests. The app can be downloaded for free off of the App Store and Google Play. Features are limited on non-football game days or if one is outside the vicinity of the stadium. However, when having the app within the stadium on game and event days one has many options including in-seat delivery, live streaming, navigation and much more. The app can be extended to other events hosted by the stadium if the third party would like to include its features for their guests.{{cite web|title=Stadium Mobile App|url=http://www.levisstadium.com/stadium-app/|website=levisstadium.com|publisher=Levi's Stadium|accessdate=October 24, 2016}} ====Issues with the turf==== The stadium has had repeated problems with the grass surface, including the grass collapsing under [[Baltimore Ravens]] kicker [[Justin Tucker]] during a week 6 game in 2015. This has led to concern that the stadium wasn't of a high enough caliber to host a high stakes game such as the [[Super Bowl]].{{cite web|last1=Cull|first1=Ian|title=More Levi's Stadium Turf Concerns After Ravens Kicker Slips During Field Goal Attempt|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/More-Levis-Stadium-Turf-Concerns-After-Ravens-Kicker-Slips-During-Field-Goal-Attempt-334369851.html|website=nbcbayarea.com|publisher=KNTV|accessdate=22 October 2015}} The problems with the turf were mentioned the day after the Super Bowl by [[Denver Broncos]] cornerback [[Aqib Talib]] who said "The footing on the field was terrible. San Fran (the 49ers) has to play eight games on that field, so they better do something to get it fixed. It was terrible."{{cite web|last1=Cull|first1=Ian|title=Broncos CB Aqib Talib says 'footing on field terrible' for Super Bowl|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/14738498/super-bowl-50-aqib-talib-denver-broncos-calls-levi-stadium-turf-terrible|website=espn.go.com|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=February 8, 2016}} ===Environmental sustainability=== Stadium proponents and those who expect to profit from the construction of the stadium claim that the stadium is currently one of the largest buildings registered with the U.S. Green Building Council. It is also believed to be the first stadium that will have both a green roof and solar panels. The 49ers are exploring collaborative opportunities with the Environmental Protection Agency to explore environmentally friendly components including: * Use of an outside commissioning agent to verify that energy‐related systems are installed, calibrated, and performing in compliance with the project requirements * Use of public transit nearby including [[Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority|VTA]], [[Altamont Corridor Express|ACE]], [[Amtrak]], with connection to a proposed future [[Silicon Valley BART extension|BART]] extension * Construction of a green roof (27,000± sf) and photovoltaic panels (20,000± sf) * Use of paving materials and roofing materials with a high solar reflectance index * Use of recycled water for landscape irrigation, toilets, and urinals along with water‐conserving fixtures * No use of CFC‐based refrigerants in the HVAC systems. Systems will instead use refrigerants that minimize compounds that contribute to ozone depletion * Installation of permanent monitoring systems that provide feedback on ventilation system performance * Diversion, recycling, and/or salvaging 75% of non‐hazardous construction waste * Use of controllable and programmable lighting control systems and thermal comfort control systems Levi's Stadium received a Gold LEED ([[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]]) Certificate. It is the first professional football stadium in the United States to receive this certification as new construction.{{cite web|url=http://www.levisstadium.com/2014/07/stadium-becomes-first-us-venue-kind-earn-leed-gold-certification/|title=Stadium Becomes First US Venue of Its Kind To Earn LEED Gold Certification - Levi's® Stadium|date=July 22, 2014|publisher=}} ===Transportation=== ====Public transit==== Stadium patrons have the option of riding [[Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority Light Rail|VTA Light Rail]] (Valley Transportation Authority) to the stadium. The closest light rail station is the [[Great America (VTA)|Great America]] station, which is located just west of the stadium in the median of Tasman Drive. To the east, other transit options include the VTA [[Lick Mill (VTA)|Lick Mill station]] (also in the Tasman median) as well as the [[Amtrak]] and [[Altamont Corridor Express|ACE]] [[Santa Clara – Great America Station|station]] near [[California's Great America]]. =====Nearby transit stations===== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|San Francisco 49ers|border=2}};|Station name !! style="text-align:center;{{NFLPrimaryStyle|San Francisco 49ers|border=2}};|Agency name |- | [[Great America (VTA)|Great America]] || [[Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority|VTA]] [[Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority Light Rail|Light Rail]] |- | [[Santa Clara – Great America Station|Santa Clara - Great America]] || [[Altamont Corridor Express|ACE]] |- | [[Santa Clara – Great America Station|Santa Clara - Great America]] || [[Amtrak]] |- |} ====Walking and bicycling==== [[File:San Tomas Aquino Creek and Levi's Stadium.JPG|thumb|right|[[San Tomas Aquino Creek]] next to Levi's Stadium]] Levi's Stadium was constructed immediately east of the San Tomas Aquino Trail, a paved multi-use path installed by the City of Santa Clara in 2004{{cite web|title=San Tomas Aquino/Saratoga Creek Trail Connector|url=http://www.baytrail.org/STA-SC.htm|website=San Francisco Bay Trail|publisher=Association of Bay Area Governments (ABAG)|accessdate=13 April 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140930234800/http://www.baytrail.org/STA-SC.htm|archivedate=September 30, 2014|df=mdy-all}} that connects to a continuous 100-mile network of off-street paths including the regional San Francisco Bay Trail. The city announced in March 2013 that the San Tomas Aquino Trail would be "temporarily detoured between Agnew Road and Tasman Drive for approximately 1 year starting April 15 and ending when the Stadium is open,{{cite news|title=San Tomas Aquino Creek Trail Temporary Detour|url=http://santaclaraca.gov/index.aspx?page=50&recordid=2052|accessdate=13 April 2015|publisher=City of Santa Clara|date=March 21, 2013}}" but this one-mile section of the trail remained closed to the public before and during stadium events since they began in August 2014, requiring the continued use of the two-mile on-street detour. The stadium project's [http://santaclaraca.gov/index.aspx?page=1560 Final Environmental Impact Report (EIR)] disclosed no such ongoing temporary closures of the trail, but stated instead that "While there will likely be a sizeable increase in pedestrians on the San Tomas Aquino Creek trail before and after NFL events, the creek trail is open to both pedestrians and cyclists and there are no restrictions on use. Anyone at anytime can access and use the trail."{{cite web|title=49ers Santa Clara Stadium Project Final Environmental Impact Report|url=http://santaclaraca.gov/modules/showdocument.aspx?documentid=12789|publisher=City of Santa Clara|accessdate=13 April 2015|page=158}} ====Vehicular access==== The stadium's official mailing address is on Marie P DeBartolo Way (formerly Centennial Boulevard), which is actually a [[cul-de-sac]] on the east side of the stadium. The primary access route to the stadium is Tasman Drive, which runs along its northern side. Tasman is a major east-west [[arterial road]] which connects to [[Interstate 880]] several miles to the east. Both west and east of the stadium, Tasman intersects with various north-south arterial roads which connect to several important freeways, such as [[U.S. Route 101]], [[California State Route 237]], and [[Interstate 280 (California)|Interstate 280]]. The closest and most important of those north-south roads is Great America Parkway to the west of the stadium, which is named after the theme park to the south. ===Naming rights=== On May 8, 2013, the 49ers announced that San Francisco-based [[Levi Strauss & Co.]] purchased the naming rights to the new stadium. The deal calls for Levi's to pay $220.3 million to the city of Santa Clara and the 49ers over 20 years, with an option to extend the deal for another five years for around $75 million.{{cite news|title=Levi's Stadium: 49ers' New Santa Clara Home Gets a Name in $220 Million Deal |first=Mike |last=Rosenberg |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/southbayfootball/ci_23198944/levis-stadium-49ers-new-santa-clara-home-gets?source=rss |newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]] |date=May 8, 2013 |accessdate=2014-07-22 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RGG74zIO?url=http://www.mercurynews.com/southbayfootball/ci_23198944/levis-stadium-49ers-new-santa-clara-home-gets |archivedate=July 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} On September 14, 2015, ESPN's [[Chris Berman]] coined the name "The Big Bellbottom" in reference to the stadium. In a [[Deadspin]] article covering the 49ers on August 18, 2015, article writer Drew Magary coined the nickname "the Jeanhole" for the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://deadspin.com/why-your-team-sucks-2015-san-francisco-49ers-1724542048|title=Why Your Team Sucks 2015: San Francisco 49ers|first=Drew|last=Magary|publisher=}} ==Reception== Levi's Stadium has been praised for its excellent sightlines, beautiful architecture, plentiful amenities, technological advancements, convenient public transportation access, and environmental sustenance.{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/place/article/Levi-s-Stadium-both-structurally-and-5752211.php|title=Levi's Stadium both structurally and architecturally impressive|publisher=}} However, the stadium has been heavily criticized for its highly corporate atmosphere and lack of a football atmosphere that Candlestick Park had. With the stadium having the most expensive ticket prices in the league during its inaugural season, many long-tenured and loyal fans that had contributed to the football atmosphere at Candlestick Park could not afford to buy season tickets with the added cost of the Stadium Builders License. Also, with the several distractions inside the stadium that include multiple bars and lounges, fans would often hang out in those places while the game is going on rather than watching the game from their seats.{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2014/11/26/kawakami-49ers-not-getting-home-field-advantage-from-new-home/|title=Kawakami: 49ers not getting home-field advantage from new home|date=November 26, 2014|publisher=}} Levi's Stadium has received some backlash from season ticket holders, who are unhappy regarding rules that won’t allow them to print their tickets until 72 hours before the game, making re-sale very difficult.{{cite web |url=http://kron4.com/2015/10/12/san-francisco-49ers-fans-voicing-frustration-about-levis-stadium/ |title=San Francisco 49ers fans voicing frustration about Levi's Stadium |author=Cestone, Vince |work=KRON4 |date=October 12, 2015 |accessdate=December 24, 2015}} In addition, older 49ers fans say that people are more segmented at Levi's Stadium in comparison to Candlestick Park, leaving [[Tailgate party|tailgaters]] with large expanses of empty parking stalls and a more desolate tailgating experience.{{cite web |url=http://blog.sfgate.com/49ers/2015/12/10/generational-split-may-be-emerging-over-acceptance-of-levis-stadium/ |title=Generational slip may be emerging over acceptance of Levi's Stadium |author=Lynch, Kevin |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=December 10, 2015 |accessdate=December 24, 2015}} Levi's Stadium has also received heavy criticism for the way fans are treated on hot days during early-season afternoon games. The majority of fans are seated on the east side of the stadium and during these afternoon games, they are exposed to the sun as there is no shade provided due to the lack of overhangs. With the climate of Santa Clara being much warmer than San Francisco, it makes watching games on hot days uncomfortable for fans as they are less accommodated for exposure to the sun than are patrons at other stadiums in hot-weather climates. Several fans suffered heat exhaustion during preseason and early season afternoon games. This has led to the eastern stands being largely empty on hot days.{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/49ers/ci_26669386/heat-takes-toll-49ers-fans-at-levis-stadium|title=Heat takes a toll on 49ers fans at Levi’s Stadium|date=October 5, 2014|publisher=}} This was the result of the stadium being designed with the Candlestick Point site in mind and when the team decided to build it in Santa Clara instead, they kept the design intact in order to quickly get started on construction not taking the differences in climate into account.{{Cite news|url=https://ninerswire.usatoday.com/2017/09/11/report-49ers-considering-ways-to-add-shade-for-fans-at-levis-stadium/|title=Report: 49ers considering ways to add shade for fans at Levi's Stadium|date=2017-09-12|work=Niners Wire|access-date=2018-08-13|language=en-US}} Due regulations by the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] for being in close proximity to the airport, they cannot add any more height to the stadium, while any additional overhangs would have to be structures, making it very difficult to fix the problem.{{Cite news|url=http://www.knbr.com/2018/08/09/49ers-say-they-cant-add-shade-at-levis-stadium-will-drop-price-of-bottled-water/|title=49ers say they can’t add shade at Levi’s Stadium, will drop price of bottled water|date=2018-08-12|work=KNBR|access-date=2018-08-13|language=en-US}} Pilots flying into [[San Jose International Airport]] have frequently complained of being blinded or disoriented by the lights from the light towers and scoreboards. The stadium is directly in the flight path of one of the airport's runways.{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/investigations/Blinded-by-the-Lights-Levi-Stadium-Lights-May-Be-Airport-Safety-Hazard-328573831.html|title=Blinded by the Lights: Levi's Stadium Lights May Be Airport Safety Hazard|publisher=[[KNTV]]|author1=Jeremy Stock|author2=Michael Bott|author3=Jeremy Carroll|date=2015-09-21}} According to Bay Area NBC affiliate [[KNTV]], there have been at least 43 complaints about the lights since the stadium opened. In response, Santa Clara mayor [[Lisa Gillmor]] promised to work with the 49ers and the Stadium Authority to determine if the lights need to be recalibrated.{{cite news|last1= Stock |first1= Stephen |last2= Bott |first2= Michael |last3= Carroll |first3= Jeremy |title= 'We Cannot Have a Major Incident': Santa Clara Mayor Wants Answers on Stadium Lights Distracting Pilots |date= 2016-11-17 |accessdate= 2017-02-26 |publisher= [[KNTV]] |url= http://www.nbcbayarea.com/investigations/We-cannot-have-a-major-incident-Santa-Clara-Mayor-Wants-Answers-on-Stadium-Lights-Distracting-Pilots-401789205.html |quote= 'Now that you’ve given me this information, we're going to follow through to make sure if there's any recalibration that needs to take place, that it takes place,' Gillmor said. 'We cannot have a major incident happen at Levi's Stadium.'}} ==Previous plans== The San Francisco 49ers played at Candlestick Park from [[1971 NFL season|1971]] to [[2013 NFL season|2013]]. The stadium was a sentimental fan favorite and housed all 5 Super Bowl Championship teams. It was, however, the oldest unrenovated stadium in the NFL and was beginning to show its age. The 49ers pursued a new stadium since 1997, when a plan for a stadium and a mall at Candlestick Point passed a public vote. When the plans failed to move forward, the San Francisco 49ers presented an alternative plan on July 18, 2006, to construct a new 68,500-seat, open air stadium as part of a mixed use development featuring housing, commercial and retail space. In November 2006 the team announced that plans for a new stadium at Candlestick Point were not feasible, “citing extensive costs for infrastructure, parking accommodations and other changes that would cost more than the stadium itself”.{{cite web |title=49ers to Leave Candlestick, Turn Focus to Santa Clara|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2654743|work=[[ESPN]]|date=April 20, 2010|accessdate=April 20, 2010}} The 49ers turned their focus to making Santa Clara the home to their new stadium. ===The 1997 plan=== San Francisco voters in 1997 approved $100 million in city spending to build a new stadium and an attached shopping mall at [[Candlestick Point]]. However, even after voter approval to grant economic help for the project, the stadium was not constructed. This was because owner [[Eddie DeBartolo, Jr.]] was facing legal troubles, which led him to surrender ownership of the team to his sister [[Denise DeBartolo York]] and brother-in-law [[John York]]. Mills Corporation, the company chosen by the 49ers, was unable to put together a plan to successfully construct a new stadium for the team. NFL owners had gone as far as awarding the new stadium the rights to host [[Super Bowl XXXVII]]. When stadium plans stalled, the game went to [[San Diego]]'s [[Qualcomm Stadium]] instead. For years, the city and team ownership were embattled over attempts to gain funding and a green-light for construction of a new stadium. None of these attempts proved to be successful. {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} ===The 2006 plan=== The city of San Francisco received a new incentive to get a new stadium built. [[Mayor of San Francisco|Mayor]] [[Gavin Newsom]] wanted to bring the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] to the city, and a new stadium would sweeten the city's proposal for selection by the [[United States Olympic Committee]] as the official US submission to the [[IOC]]. The announcement came in November 2006. It called for a new stadium that would be converted into a 68,600-seat stadium for the 49ers after the Olympics. The [[Olympic Village]] would be converted into low-income housing after the games were over.{{cite news|title=Newsom's Olympic Vision Sees New 49ers Stadium |first=Phillip |last=Matier |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/07/11/MNG03JT3ET1.DTL |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=July 11, 2006 |accessdate=January 1, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604141440/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2006%2F07%2F11%2FMNG03JT3ET1.DTL |archivedate=June 4, 2011 |df= }} The new stadium was to be built at Candlestick Point on land just southeast of Candlestick Park. The cost of the stadium would be $916 million. Lennar Corporation would build housing, retail, and office space around the stadium area.{{cite news |title=First Look at 49ers' Stadium Plan|first=Robert|last=Selna|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/07/18/BAGTVK0N891.DTL|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=July 18, 2006|accessdate=January 1, 2007}} Originally, part of the area surrounding Candlestick Park was to be zoned for retail space and housing; the new 49ers stadium was to be combined with such elements, bringing much-needed attractions to the historically blighted neighborhood of [[Hunters Point, San Francisco, California|Hunters Point]].{{cite news |title=SAN FRANCISCO / New neighborhood in Hunters Point is Near Ready to Build / First 1,500 Homes at Old Shipyard Called 'Hilltop Community'|first1=Robert|last1=Selna|first2=Heather|last2=Knight|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2006-11-10/bay-area/17319069_1_candlestick-point-lennar-corp-bayview-hunters-point|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=November 10, 2006|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} The stadium would be stocked with 150 luxury suites, 7,500 premium club seats, and an increased number of seats lower and closer to the field, called "bowl seating," potentially raising the 49ers franchise value up as much as $250 million and offering at least $300 million in advertising and concession deals, the majority of which from paid corporate naming.{{cite news |title=Deluxe Stadium May Enrich 49ers|first=Mike|last=Swift|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/search/ci_4716566|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=November 24, 2006|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} The architectural design would be reminiscent of San Francisco buildings. The project planning did not get off to a good start, however, with contention between the 49ers and the city of San Francisco over viable locations for the new stadium. Initially, the idea was to build a stadium in the parking lot of Candlestick Park and later demolish the aging stadium. Team ownership feared that construction of the village and the stadium would severely limit the amount of land available in Candlestick Point, creating a parking problem for fans and increasing traffic along the roads that link the stadium to the freeway. Moreover, with residents in the low-income housing by 2016, traffic would be permanently increased, further damaging the already-limited methods of transportation to the park.{{cite web | title=Letter to 49ers Faithful | url=http://49ers.com/pressbox/news_detail.php?PRKey=2515 | author=Denise and John York | date=November 9, 2006 | publisher=San Francisco 49ers | accessdate=January 1, 2007 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928071225/http://49ers.com/pressbox/news_detail.php?PRKey=2515 | archivedate=September 28, 2007}} With San Francisco slow to come up with better locations for the stadium or ways to circumvent the problems posed by construction at Candlestick Point, team owners [[Denise DeBartolo York]] and [[John York]] announced on November 9, 2006, that the 49ers were shifting their efforts to create a new stadium to the city of Santa Clara, home to the team offices and training facility since 1987, approximately {{convert|40|mi|km}} south of San Francisco. The sudden removal of the planned stadium forced the San Francisco Olympics bid group to cancel its proposal,{{cite news | title='Shocked' S.F. Group Drops Bid for 2016 Olympics | first=John | last=Crumpacker | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/11/14/MNG5JMCADR1.DTL&hw=Olympics+San+Francisco&sn=003&sc=857 | newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date=November 14, 2006 | accessdate=January 25, 2013}} which engendered great anger not only from Mayor Newsom, but also from such 49ers legends as [[Joe Montana]] and [[Ronnie Lott]], who were part of the effort to bring the Olympics to the Bay Area. In addition, many fans were outraged at the suggestion to move the 49ers out of the city that it had shared history with for decades. The Yorks insisted that the legacy of the franchise would be respected in the sense that the 49ers would not be renamed nor moved out of the [[Bay Area]]. This was met with much opposition from Mayor Newsom and [[US Senate|Senator]] [[Dianne Feinstein]] (who was [[mayor of San Francisco]] between 1978 and 1988); the senator stated that the team should be unable to use the San Francisco name if its operations were not based in the city.{{cite web |title=Sen. Feinstein May Write 49ers Stadium Bill|url=http://cbs5.com/topstories/local_story_318105309.html|work=[[KPIX-TV|KPIX]]|location=San Francisco|date=November 14, 2006|accessdate=January 1, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114222813/http://cbs5.com/topstories/local_story_318105309.html|archivedate=November 14, 2006}} On January 3, 2007, [[California State Senate|California State Senator]] [[Carole Migden]] introduced a bill, entitled SB49, that would bar the 49ers from building a new stadium within a {{convert|100|mi|km|adj=on}} radius of San Francisco, if they were to leave the city. The 49ers organization announced its strong opposition to the legislation and retorted that passing such a bill would only encourage the team to move out of the Bay Area altogether.{{cite web |title=Letter to 49ers Faithful - 49ers, Senator Alquist Announce Opposition to SB 49|url=http://www.sf49ers.com/pressbox/news_detail.php?PRKey=2738§ion=PR%20News|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927195750/http://www.sf49ers.com/pressbox/news_detail.php?PRKey=2738§ion=PR%20News|dead-url=yes|archive-date=September 27, 2007|publisher=San Francisco 49ers|accessdate=January 6, 2007}} The bill died without being acted upon.{{cite web |title=SB 49 Senate Bill - History|url=http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/pub/07-08/bill/sen/sb_0001-0050/sb_49_bill_20080204_history.html|publisher=California State Legislature|accessdate=December 25, 2014}} ==Santa Clara City Council Negotiations== The Santa Clara stadium project had been in the works since 2007, with negotiations beginning in 2008. Two years later the following documents were produced that were key to understanding the stadium deal that went before the voters of Santa Clara on June 8, 2010. All documents cited below are publicly available on the City of Santa Clara’s website. * Term Sheet: Detailed agreement between the city of Santa Clara and the San Francisco 49ers about the financing, construction, operation, and eventual demolition of the stadium. Key points include: no new or increased city taxes or costs to residents; 49ers responsible for construction and operation cost overruns; and the city will continue to own the land and receive rent payments back to its general fund from the stadium.{{cite web |title=49ers Santa Clara Stadium Term Sheet|url=http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49ers-20090601-term-sheet.pdf |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100423175055/http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49ers-20090601-term-sheet.pdf |archive-date= 2010-04-23 |publisher=City of Santa Clara|date=June 1, 2009|accessdate=April 20, 2010}} * 49ers Stadium Proposal: A PowerPoint presentation given to the City of Santa Clara April 24, 2007.{{cite web|title=49ers Stadium Proposal|url=http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49ers-20070424-stadium-proposal.pdf|publisher=City of Santa Clara|date=April 24, 2007|accessdate=April 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527124624/http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49ers-20070424-stadium-proposal.pdf|archivedate=May 27, 2010|df=mdy-all}} * Study: Economic and Fiscal Impacts of a New State-of-the-Art Stadium in Santa Clara: This is a study conducted by Conventions Sports and Leisure (CSL). It highlights estimates of a new stadium’s economic and fiscal impact on the City of Santa Clara and the region including the creation of new jobs and new economic activity.{{cite web|title=Economic and Fiscal Impacts of a New State-of-the-Art Stadium in Santa Clara|url=http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49ers-EFIR.pdf|publisher=City of Santa Clara|accessdate=April 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527140519/http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49ers-EFIR.pdf|archivedate=May 27, 2010|df=mdy-all}} * Environmental Impact Report: This document is part of the state-mandated California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) process. It researches in depth all possible environmental impacts the stadium may have.{{cite web|title=Environmental Impact Report|url=http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49er-stadium-FEIR/49ers-feir.pdf|publisher=City of Santa Clara|accessdate=April 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100404163026/http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49er-stadium-FEIR/49ers-feir.pdf|archivedate=April 4, 2010|df=mdy-all}} Most city council members in Santa Clara were extremely receptive to the possibility of a new stadium being constructed there for the 49ers. In 2009, the Santa Clara City Council, led by Mayor Patricia Mahan, along with city employees began negotiating in earnest with the team, who presented the city with stadium plans. On June 2, 2009, by a 5-2 vote, the Santa Clara city council agreed to preliminary terms (as detailed in a term sheet{{cite web|url=http://49ers.savesantaclara.org/pdf/49ers-20090601-term-sheet.pdf|title=49ers term sheet|publisher=}}). The official term sheet stated that the team's name would not change; the team would continue to be called the San Francisco 49ers even when the move to Santa Clara was complete.{{cite web |title=Niners Show Santa Clara Officials Plans for New $937 Million Stadium|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d8114e703&template=without-video-with-comments&confirm=true|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=July 15, 2009|accessdate=February 1, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.supportourniners.com/stadium_design.php |title=000webhost.com - free web hosting provider |publisher=Supportourniners.com |accessdate=February 1, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100227085604/http://www.supportourniners.com/stadium_design.php |archivedate=February 27, 2010 }} ==The campaign== ===Santa Clara stadium campaign=== In December 2009, [[Cedar Fair|Cedar Fair Entertainment]], Great America's owner, filed a lawsuit to stop the project from proceeding.{{cite news|title=Lawsuit Could Stall 49ers' Santa Clara Stadium |first=John |last=Coté |url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2009-12-09/news/17182707_1_santa-clara-city-council-theme-park-amusement-park |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=December 9, 2009 |accessdate=February 11, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927023648/http://articles.sfgate.com/2009-12-09/news/17182707_1_santa-clara-city-council-theme-park-amusement-park |archivedate=September 27, 2011 }} However, the lawsuit was dismissed in court. On December 15, 2009, the Santa Clara City Council voted 5-2 to withdraw their city-sponsored ballot measure on the stadium issue in favor of a ballot initiative, Measure J.{{cite web |title=Santa Clara Backs 49ers-Sponsored Stadium Ballot Initiative|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/article/135655|work=SportsBusiness Daily|date=December 14, 2009|accessdate=February 1, 2013}} The ballot initiative was voted on on June 8, 2010 and passed by 58% of Santa Clara voters.{{cite web |title=Measure J: Lease of City Land - Santa Clara County, CA|url=http://www.smartvoter.org/2010/06/08/ca/scl/meas/J/|publisher=Smartvoter.org|accessdate=February 1, 2013}}{{cite news |title=Santa Clara: 49er Stadium Proposal Named Measure J|first=Howard|last=Mintz|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_14710946|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=March 19, 2010|accessdate=April 1, 2010}} Santa Clara City Council members William Kennedy and Jamie McLeod had opposed the stadium project and worked (unsuccessfully) to get Measure J defeated.{{cite news |title=49ers Stadium Campaign is David vs. Goliath Affair|first=Howard|last=Mintz|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_14798691|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=April 1, 2010|accessdate=April 1, 2010}} ===Measure J: June 8, 2010=== Measure J is a binding, voter-initiated measure that was approved by voters in the City of Santa Clara. All documents cited below are publicly available on the City of Santa Clara’s official website. * Ballot Question: This is the question that was presented to voters:{{cite web|title=Measure J Ballot Question|url=http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49ers-20100209-ballot-questions.pdf|publisher=City of Santa Clara|date=February 9, 2010|accessdate=April 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100423175129/http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/csc/pdf/49ers-20100209-ballot-questions.pdf|archivedate=April 23, 2010|df=mdy-all}} ** Shall the City of Santa Clara adopt Ordinance 17.20 leasing City property for a professional football stadium and other events; no use of City General or Enterprise funds for construction; no new taxes for residents for stadium; Redevelopment Agency funds capped for construction; private party pays all construction cost overruns; no City/Agency obligation for stadium operating/maintenance; private party payment of projected fair market rent; and additional funds for senior/youth/library/recreation to City’s General Fund? * Voter Ordinance: This city ordinance becomes law if Santa Clara voters approve Measure J.{{cite web|title=Measure J Voter Ordinance|url=http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/CSC/PDF/49ers-stadium-initiative-citizen-led.pdf|publisher=City of Santa Clara|accessdate=April 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527124705/http://santaclaraca.gov/ftp/CSC/PDF/49ers-stadium-initiative-citizen-led.pdf|archivedate=May 27, 2010|df=mdy-all}} ===Election results=== {{Referendum | title = Measure J (June 8, 2010)[http://www.sccgov.org/elections/results/jun082010/ Elections Results] from [[Santa Clara County, California]] retrieved 22 June 2014 | yes = 14,782 | yespct = 58.2 | no = 10,505 | nopct = 41.8 | total = 25,133 }} ==Oakland Raiders as possible co-tenants== There was a possibility that the [[Oakland Raiders]] might share the stadium, allowing its costs to be split between the two teams.{{cite news |title=NFL May Bribe Raiders, 49ers Into Shotgun Wedding|first=Joe|last=Kukura|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/sports/NFL-May-Bribe-Raiders-49ers-Into-Shotgun-Wedding-96172874.html|work=[[KNTV]]|location=San Francisco|date=September 29, 2010|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} The stadium is designed to accommodate two teams, with the exterior LEDs being programmable for alternate colors and two home-team locker rooms.{{cite news |title=Renewed talks of Raiders-49ers sharing Levi's Stadium |first= |last= |url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/74313994-story |work=[[KTVU]] |location= |date=January 13, 2016 |accessdate=January 14, 2016}} The 49ers and Raiders{{cite news |title=Davis Doesn't Deny That Raiders Could Share Stadium With 49ers|first=Sajid|last=Farooq|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Al-Davis-Doesnt-Deny-That-Raiders-Could-Share-Stadium-With-49ers-114173599.html|work=[[KNTV]]|location=San Francisco|date=January 18, 2011|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} publicly said it would be an option if possible, while NFL commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] was strongly in favor of the two sharing a stadium.{{cite web |title=Roger Goodell Talks of Stadium Issues|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=5672050|work=[[ESPN]]|date=October 10, 2010|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} Fans of both teams reacted negatively to the idea. Along with the [[New York metropolitan area]], where the [[New York Giants]] and [[New York Jets]] shared [[Giants Stadium]] from 1984 to 2009 and currently share its successor, [[MetLife Stadium]], the DC-Baltimore metro area and Los Angeles. The Bay Area is one of 4 NFL markets with two teams. The 49ers and Raiders sharing a stadium would not have been a first, as the two shared [[Kezar Stadium]] for part of 1960.{{cite web |title=1960 Oakland Raiders Statistics & Players |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/rai/1960.htm|publisher=Pro-Football-Reference|accessdate=February 1, 2013}} It would have also fulfilled the late Raiders owner [[Al Davis]]' goal of a new stadium, something he had strongly desired since the late 1980s although Davis was against sharing a new stadium with another NFL team in Los Angeles when the idea was proposed to him, prompting his move back to Oakland in 1995.{{cite news |title=PRO FOOTBALL; Raiders Run a Reverse Play Back to Oakland|first=Timothy W.|last=Smith|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/24/sports/pro-football-raiders-run-a-reverse-play-back-to-oakland.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 24, 1995|accessdate=February 11, 2014}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/blog/los-angeles/nfl/post/_/id/97/al-davis-is-back-where-he-started|title=The day Al Davis walked away|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-07-30|language=en}} The Raiders, as it stands, play at the [[Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum]] and are the only NFL team still sharing its home field with a [[Major League Baseball]] team; the Raiders' lease on the Coliseum has been on year-to-year extensions since the expiration of the last long-term lease in 2013.{{cite web |title=Vikings in Limbo and Expansion Not on NFL's Radar|first1=Dave|last1=Campbell|first2=John|last2=Krawczynski|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/vikings-limbo-expansion-not-nfls-173245299--nfl.html|work=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|date=May 7, 2012|accessdate=May 7, 2012}} In the wake of Davis' death, the possibility of the 49ers and Raiders sharing the stadium became a stronger possibility. However, by October 2011, the 49ers were far enough along on the stadium to have reportedly already sold over a quarter of the [[Luxury box|luxury suites]], meaning the Raiders would be forced to be secondary tenants.{{cite web |title=Raiders' Relocation Scenarios Take on New Dynamic|first=Michael|last=Silver|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=ms-silver_al_davis_raiders_relocation_la_stadium101011|work=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|date=October 10, 2011|accessdate=February 1, 2013}} In October 2012, [[Oakland Raiders]] owner [[Mark Davis (American football)|Mark Davis]] told reporters he had no plans to share the Santa Clara stadium with the 49ers. According to the report, discussions remained open, although Davis wanted to keep the team in Oakland, or a nearby site in [[Dublin, California|Dublin]].{{cite web |title=Oakland Raiders Have No Plans to Share Stadium with 49ers|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000081194/article/oakland-raiders-have-no-plans-to-share-stadium-with-49ers?module=HP11_headline_stack|publisher=[[National Football League]]|date=October 16, 2012|accessdate=February 1, 2013}} When the stadium had its grand opening on July 17, 2014, Goodell mentioned to the live crowd that it would make a great home for the Raiders and that it was up for the team to decide whether or not it wanted to play there or build a stadium on the site of the Oakland Coliseum. While the 49ers remained open to sharing the stadium with the Raiders, the Raiders said that their personal preference was the Coliseum site.[http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/11229559/roger-goodell-floats-san-francisco-49ers-levi-stadium-oakland-raiders-option Goodell: Levi's might fit Raiders] [[ESPN.com]] (07/18/2014) On February 20, 2015, the Raiders announced that they would be seeking a [[Carson Stadium|joint stadium]] in [[Carson, California|Carson]], with the [[San Diego Chargers]] should they not receive public funding to replace the Oakland Coliseum, reducing the likelihood of the Raiders sharing Levi's Stadium with the 49ers.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-nfl-stadium-20150220-story.html#page=1|title=Chargers, Raiders will jointly pursue an NFL stadium in Carson|first=Sam|last=Farmer|date=February 20, 2015|publisher=|via=LA Times}} In January 2016, after losing their bid to relocate to Los Angeles to the [[Los Angeles Rams]], the Raiders withdrew their request to move to Los Angeles, and joint tenancy at Levi's again surfaced in general discussion. However, with the [[Oakland Raiders relocation to Las Vegas|Raiders getting approved for a move to Las Vegas]] and securing a local agreement for stadium funding there with [[Las Vegas Stadium]] under construction, it seems unlikely the Raiders will ever pursue a move to Santa Clara. ==Financing and construction== In December 2011, the Santa Clara City Council voted for an agreement that calls for the city’s Stadium Authority to borrow $850 million from [[Goldman Sachs]], [[Bank of America]] and [[U.S. Bank]]. This will cover most of the construction costs, with the remainder to be made up via funding from the NFL, a hotel tax and city redevelopment funds. Interest, fees and terms for this loan have not been disclosed.{{cite news |title=49ers, Santa Clara Secure Funding for New Stadium|url=http://omaha.stats.com/fb/story.asp?i=20111203134552085620508&ref=hea&tm=&src=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426021044/http://omaha.stats.com/fb/story.asp?i=20111203134552085620508&ref=hea&tm=&src=|dead-url=yes|archive-date=April 26, 2012|newspaper=[[Omaha World-Herald]]|date=December 3, 2011|accessdate=December 3, 2011}}{{cite web|title=New Santa Clara Stadium Update|first=Scott|last=Kegley|url=http://blog.49ers.com/2011/12/03/new-santa-clara-stadium-update/|publisher=San Francisco 49ers|date=December 3, 2011|accessdate=December 3, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206052607/http://blog.49ers.com/2011/12/03/new-santa-clara-stadium-update/|archivedate=December 6, 2011|df=mdy-all}} The $850 million building loan, plus interest and fees will be assumed by the City's Stadium Authority, where additional interest and fees will be applied. On February 2, 2012, NFL owners approved a loan to the 49ers of $200 million for use in constructing the new stadium, and to be taken from a new G-4 stadium loan fund.{{cite news |title=NFL Owners Approve $200 Million Loan for 49ers Stadium|first=Howard|last=Mintz|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_19878108|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=February 3, 2012|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} Terms of the loan were not specified, but under the previous G-3 plan, money was repaid directly into the league's account from the borrowing team's share of gate receipts from road games. ==Construction== [[File:49ers New Stadium 2 2013-07-11.jpg|thumb|Levi's Stadium under construction, July 11, 2013]] Construction began soon after funding for the stadium had been confirmed. The official groundbreaking took place on April 19, 2012. On July 30, 2012, the first steel beams for the stadium were laid down.{{cite news |title=San Francisco 49ers Stadium Beams Rise from the Dirt in Santa Clara|first=Mike|last=Rosenburg|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_21193791/san-francisco-49ers-stadium-beams-rise-from-dirt|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=April 19, 2012|accessdate=February 1, 2013}} The first seats in Levi's Stadium were installed on October 1, 2013. Construction was halted on June 11, 2013, after a mechanic working on an elevator was struck by a counterweight and then fell down the shaft to his death.{{cite news |title=Work Halted at New Levi's Stadium After Elevator Mechanic Killed|first1=Robert|last1=Salonga|first2=Mike|last2=Gomez|first3=Mike|last3=Rosenburg|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_23434632/santa-clara-person-dies-at-site-new-49ers|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=June 11, 2013|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} Work resumed two days later after officials from the [[California Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] (Cal/OSHA) declared the site safe, but as of October 2013, the accident remained under investigation.{{cite news |title=Construction Workers Return to Levi's Stadium|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Stadium-Workers-Return-to-New-49ers-Stadium-211378871.html|work=[[KNTV]]|location=San Francisco|date=June 13, 2013|accessdate=June 13, 2013}}{{cite news |title=Cal OSHA Reopens Investigation Into Elevator Worker’s Death At Levi’s Stadium|url=http://sacramento.cbslocal.com/2013/10/23/cal-osha-reopens-investigation-into-elevator-workers-death-at-new-49ers-stadium/|work=[[KOVR]]|location=Sacramento|publisher=[[Associated Press]]|date=October 23, 2013|accessdate=January 29, 2014}} The Santa Clara stadium was constructed on a city-owned parking lot on Tasman Drive, located adjacent to the north of [[California's Great America]] theme park and leased to Great America for overflow parking. As with Candlestick Park, there are relatively few amenities in the stadium's immediate vicinity for sports fans, besides the 49ers headquarters and training facility. The [[Santa Clara Convention Center]] is northwest of the stadium site and there are two hotels on Tasman Drive next to the convention center, but the closest significant concentration of hotels and restaurants is on the Mission College Boulevard corridor almost a mile to the south, on the other side of Great America. ==Opening== [[File:Entering Levi's Stadium.JPG|thumb|Levi's Stadium on August 2, 2014, hosting its first-ever game, a soccer match featuring the [[San Jose Earthquakes]] and [[Seattle Sounders FC]].]] The stadium opened on July 17, 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/southbayfootball/ci_26168577/49ers-open-levis-stadium-show-stopping-nfl-ceremony|title=49ers open Levi's Stadium with showstopping NFL ceremony|work=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|date=July 17, 2014|first=Mike|last= Rosenberg|accessdate=July 17, 2014}} It was originally scheduled to open on July 11, but was pushed back due to construction delays. The first game played at the new stadium was a [[Major League Soccer]] match on August 2, 2014, where the [[2014 San Jose Earthquakes season|San Jose Earthquakes]] defeated [[2014 Seattle Sounders FC season|Seattle Sounders FC]] 1–0 before a crowd of 48,765. The inaugural goal was scored in the 42nd minute by [[Yannick Djaló]].[http://www.soccerbyives.net/2014/08/earthquakes-sounders-stadium.html "EARTHQUAKES UPSET SOUNDERS TO OPEN LEVI’S STADIUM"], Soccer By Ives, August 3, 2014. On August 17, 2014, the [[2014 San Francisco 49ers season|49ers]] lost their first preseason game, 34–0, against the [[2014 Denver Broncos season|Denver Broncos]] at Levi's Stadium. One fan at the game collapsed due to the heat and had to be rushed to a local hospital, where he died.{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/11369709/man-collapsed-san-francisco-49ers-preseason-game-levi-stadium-dies |title=Man who collapsed during San Francisco 49ers preseason game at Levi's Stadium dies |author=Associated Press |publisher=ESPN |date=18 August 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-18}} The first 49ers' regular-season game at the stadium was held during Week 2 on September 14, 2014, when the team hosted the [[2014 Chicago Bears season|Chicago Bears]] on ''[[NBC Sunday Night Football|Sunday Night Football]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.ninersnation.com/2014/4/23/5643678/49ers-2014-schedule-dates-games-home-away |title=San Francisco 49ers 2014 schedule: Dates, game times, strength of schedule and more |author=David Fucillo |publisher=Niners Nation |date=Apr 23, 2014 |accessdate=2014-04-24}} The Bears won the game 28–20{{cite web|author=[[Associated Press]] |url=http://abc7chicago.com/sports/brandon-marshall-makes-2-tds-via-jay-cutler-to-beat-49ers/309104/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140918040122/http://abc7chicago.com/sports/brandon-marshall-makes-2-tds-via-jay-cutler-to-beat-49ers/309104/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 18, 2014 |title=BRANDON MARSHALL MAKES 3 TDS VIA JAY CUTLER TO BEAT 49ERS |publisher=[[WLS-TV]] |date=September 14, 2014 |accessdate=September 17, 2014 }} in front of a 49ers home record attendance of 70,799.{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/liveupdate/gamecenter/56200/SF_Gamebook.pdf |title=Bears-49ers Gamebook |author=National Football League |publisher=nfl.com |date=2014-09-17 |accessdate=2014-09-22}} ==Weekdays and parking== In November 2013, stadium and 49ers' officials initially requested the [[National Football League|NFL]] to not schedule any [[Monday Night Football|Monday]] or [[Thursday Night Football|Thursday]] night home games during Levi's Stadium's inaugural season due to parking issues in the area surrounding the stadium during weekdays.{{cite news |title=Lack Of Parking Means No Monday Night Football At Levi's Stadium|first=Phil|last=Matier|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2013/12/09/phil-matier-lack-of-parking-means-no-monday-night-football-at-levis-stadium/|work=[[KPIX]]|location=San Francisco|date=December 9, 2013|accessdate=December 31, 2013}} Two months later, in January 2014, the Santa Clara city government was able to secure more than the 21,000 necessary parking spots by approving use of the fairways at the city-owned Santa Clara Golf and Tennis Club (which is located to the north of the stadium across Tasman Drive). This arrangement is similar to and was modeled upon a longstanding arrangement between the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]] in [[Pasadena, California]] and the adjacent [[Brookside Golf Course]], where the golf course was modified to allow for vehicular access to the fairways; they are used for parking only when dry to minimize damage, and any damage that does occur is repaired afterward. With access to the golf course fairways, Levi's Stadium now had 31,600 potential parking spaces, meaning that tailgating and weeknight games were now a possibility. However, the NFL decided not to schedule any weeknight home games at Levi's Stadium in 2014 until traffic flow within the area is figured out, with the exception of a [[NFL on Thanksgiving Day|Thanksgiving]] game between the 49ers and the [[2014 Seattle Seahawks season|Seattle Seahawks]] on November 27, 2014. Parking prices, which averaged $30 in the 49ers' final season at Candlestick Park, will increase to $40 at Levi's Stadium.{{cite news |title=49ers Surpass Goal for Parking Spots at New Levi's Stadium|first=Matt|last=Keller|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/sports/pro/football&id=9394650|work=[[KGO-TV|KGO]]|location=San Francisco|date=January 15, 2014|accessdate=January 17, 2014}} Anticipating significant traffic from Levi's Stadium visitors, the nearby city of [[Mountain View, California|Mountain View]] instituted a three-hour parking limit on downtown streets during game days. While residents received exemptions via permit tags, stadium-goers must park in paid lots or far from Mountain View's Caltrain/VTA light rail station. This station is the closest VTA light rail station to San Francisco and receives transferring passengers heading south to San Jose via light rail (including people using the light rail to go directly to the Levi's Stadium station).{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_26074010/mountain-view-council-approves-pilot-parking-program-address|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|accessdate=August 15, 2014 |date=July 2, 2014| title=Mountain View: Council approves pilot parking program to address impacts from Levi's Stadium |last=Green |first=Jason}} In Spring 2015, 49ers' officials offered the city of Santa Clara $15 million to take over the adjacent Santa Clara Youth Soccer Park and convert these soccer fields into additional parking lots. This money, along with a large percentage of parking fees, would have then been used for the city to build a new youth sports complex elsewhere.{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_27953862/santa-clara-critics-pan-49ers-15-million-offer?source=infinite|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|accessdate=June 6, 2015 |date=April 20, 2015| title=Santa Clara: Critics pan 49ers' $15 million offer to take over youth soccer fields |last=Rodriguez |first=Joe}} The plan was opposed by the youth soccer leagues that use the fields, and critics calling it a "land grab".{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Dispute-Between-49ers-Santa-Clara-Youth-Soccer-Leagues-Over-Fields-Near-Levis-Stadium-300733471.html|work=[[KNTV-TV]]/NBC Bay Area|accessdate=June 6, 2015 |date=April 20, 2015| title=Dispute Between 49ers, Santa Clara Youth Soccer Leagues Over Fields Near Levi's Stadium}} After many youth soccer players attended a city council meeting on April 29 to protest the proposal, the 49ers withdrew the $15 million offer.{{cite news|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2015/04/29/49ers-pull-15m-offer-for-fields-after-youth-soccer-players-take-stand/|work=[[KPIX-TV]]/CBS San Francisco|accessdate=June 6, 2015 |date=April 29, 2015| title=49ers Pull $15M Offer For Fields After Youth Soccer Players Take Stand}} The team then gave the city an unsolicited offer of $3 million to help improve various youth athletic fields and facilities, which was cited as a peace offering by ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' columnists Phil Matier and Andrew Ross, and other Bay Area media,{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/matier-ross/article/Niners-can-t-give-it-away-Santa-Clara-nixes-6263392.php|work=SFgate.com|accessdate=June 6, 2015 |date=May 14, 2015| title=Santa Clara City Council rejects 49ers’ $3 million peace offering | authors=Phil Matier and Andrew Ross}} but the city council turned the offer down.{{cite news|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2015/05/14/santa-clara-city-council-rejects-49ers-3-million-donation-to-help-youth-sports/|work=[[KCBS-AM]]/CBS San Francisco|accessdate=June 6, 2015 |date=May 14, 2015| title=Santa Clara City Council Rejects 49ers $3 Million Donation To Help Youth Sports}} ==Other events== [[File:Super Bowl 50 (24922945221).jpg|thumb|[[Super Bowl 50]] at Levi's Stadium]] ===Super Bowl 50=== {{see also|Super Bowl 50}} Super Bowl 50 was held at the stadium on February 7, 2016. The [[Denver Broncos]] defeated the [[Carolina Panthers]] 24–10. [[Lady Gaga]] performed the national anthem, and [[Coldplay]] performed with [[Beyoncé]] and [[Bruno Mars]] at halftime.{{cite news|last1=O'Connell|first1=Michael|title=Super Bowl 50 TV Ratings Fall Shy of Record|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/super-bowl/6867377/super-bowl-50-tv-ratings|accessdate=8 February 2016|work=Billboard|publisher=Billboard|date=8 February 2016|ref=Super Bowl 50 TV Ratings Fall Shy of Record}} ===WrestleMania 31=== [[File:WrestleMania 31 stage.jpg|thumb|right|WrestleMania 31]] Levi's Stadium hosted [[WWE]]'s [[WrestleMania 31]] on March 29, 2015. This was the first time [[WrestleMania]] was hosted in Northern California and the sixth WrestleMania to be held in [[California]]. The area also hosted various activities in the week-long celebration leading up to WrestleMania itself.{{cite web |title=Bay Area to Host WrestleMania XXXI|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/levis-stadium-to-host-wrestlemania-XXXI-26168855|publisher=[[WWE]]|date=December 9, 2013|accessdate=December 11, 2013}} The show set an attendance record for the stadium, with 76,976. It drew a $12.6 million gate.[http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/fighting/article16882253.html "WWE WrestleMania record setting again", WWE press release, via ''The Miami Herald''.] ===Ice hockey=== Levi's Stadium hosted the [[2015 NHL Stadium Series]]' February 21 game between the [[Los Angeles Kings]] and [[San Jose Sharks]].{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/nhl/2014/08/06/san-jose-sharks-los-angeles-kings-stadium-series|title=Sharks, Kings to play in 2015 NHL Stadium Series|work=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=August 6, 2014|accessdate=August 6, 2014}} The Kings defeated the Sharks 2-1, in front of a crowd of 70,205.{{cite news|last=Pollak|first=David|date=2015-02-21|title=Kings edge Sharks at Levi's Stadium|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/sharks/ci_27576901/kings-edge-sharks-at-levis-stadium|newspaper=San Jose Mercury News|access-date=2015-02-23}} ===Soccer=== On July 31, 2014, the [[San Jose Earthquakes]] agreed to play one match per year for five years at Levi's Stadium.{{cite web |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/earthquakes/ci_26252488/earthquakes-have-5-year-deal-49ers-play-at |title=Earthquakes have 5-year deal with 49ers to play at Levi's |publisher=San Jose Mercury News |accessdate=August 3, 2014 }} On September 6, 2014, an international friendly between [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] and [[Chile national football team|Chile]] was held.{{cite web|title=Announced: Mexico vs. Chile on Sept. 6 at Levi’s® Stadium|url=http://www.sjearthquakes.com/news/2014/07/announced-mexico-vs-chile-sept-6-levis%C2%AE-stadium|website=SJEarthquakes.com|accessdate=22 August 2014}} The stadium also hosted a [[2015 International Champions Cup]] match between [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] and [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on July 25, 2015, when United won 3–1. A [[2016 International Champions Cup]] match featured [[A.C. Milan]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on July 30, 2016, with Liverpool winning 2–0.{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/sports/ci_29670689/liverpool-fc-face-ac-milan-at-levis-stadium/|title=Liverpool FC to face AC Milan at Levi’s Stadium in July|date=March 22, 2016|publisher=}} In June 2016, Levi's Stadium hosted four games at the [[Copa América Centenario]]; the opening match between [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] and [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]], two other group stage matches, and a quarter-final where [[Chile national football team|Chile]] defeated [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]].{{cite web|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/soccer/2015/12/17/levis-stadium-to-host-usa-argentina-for-copa-america-centenario/|title=Levi’s Stadium to host USA, Argentina for Copa America Centenario|date=December 17, 2015|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ninersnation.com/2016/2/21/11086322/2016-copa-america-centenario-draw-us-to-face-colombia-in-levis/|title=Copa América Centenario matches at Levi's Stadium|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/report?gameId=444701|title=Mexico vs. Chile - Football Match Report - June 19, 2016 - ESPN|website=ESPN.com}} A [[2017 International Champions Cup]] game was held on July 23, 2017, when Manchester United defeated Real Madrid 1-1 (2-1 in a penalty shootout). On March 23, 2018, [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] won 3–0 against [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] in a friendly in both teams' preparation for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/soccer/la-sp-mexico-iceland-20180323-story.html|title=Mexico defeats Iceland in World Cup tuneup|website=latimes.com}} A [[2018 International Champions Cup]] game was held on August 4, 2018, when AC Milan defeated FC Barcelona 1-0 with a last second goal by [[André Silva (footballer, born 1995)|André Silva]]. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left;
